Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Detailed comment: postposional affix -nge

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Comment: The order ANM - N is claimed to be strict.

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Example: INCL bEdE vs. EXCL mangE

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Detailed comment: 1SG bE, 2SG tSE, 3SG NgaN, 1PL bEdE/mangE, 2PL ta, 3PL NgaNlE

Feature: Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Detailed comment: 1SG bE, 2SG tSE, 3SG NgaN, 1PL bEdE/mangE, 2PL ta, 3PL NgaNlE

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Detailed comment: 2-way distinction
Example:
EnE ‘this’ - EnElE ‘these’
mE(r) ‘that’ - mE(r)lE ‘those’

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Comment: “They encode a two-way distinction between proximal (ənə) and distal (nokə). The third demonstrative (thər) indicates a referent that is out of sight.”
Example:
ənə ‘this’
nokə ‘that’
thər ‘that out of sight’

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Detailed comment: Suffix -la

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Comment: It is not productive. In general, number marking is not obligatory.
Detailed comment: Suffix -NgE/-gE
Example: taS@ [stone] - taSEN-g@ [stone-SG], kuN [person] - kuN-g@ [person-SG]

Feature: Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Detailed comment: Suffix =Rala

Feature: Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Detailed comment: -la
Example:
bendZer-la [bird-PL]
agu=la [girl-PL]
səme=la=nə [god.box=PL=ACC] ‘god boxes’

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
aku=ts_haN [girl=ASSOC] ‘girl’s family’
dz’oma=ts_haN=sa k_hoN=g@ o k_h@r-na
[Droma=ASSOC=ABL person=SG.INDEF go be.required-DUR]
‘A person from Droma’s family should go.’
tundaX @n@ dz’oma=ts_haN doXdaXap-g@-tC@
[matter this Droma=ASSOC=ACC hurt-VBZ-PFV]
‘This matter wounded Droma’s family.’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Example:
nok@ au=n@ k_holdaku
[that man=ACC shoe]
‘that man’s shoe’
nok@ au=n@ papa
[that man=ACC father]
‘that man’s father’
nok@ au=n@ n@r
[that man=ACC face]
‘that man’s face]

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Comment: Controversial sources: Fried (2010): possessor is marked, possessed unmarked; Todaeva (1997): possessor is marked on the possessed in phrases with pronominal possessor, no information on phrases with nominal possessor. According to Fried (2010), the order would be 1, according to Todaeva (1997) 2.
Example:
Todaeva (1997): bEndZEr [bird] - bEndZer-nE [bird-3SG/PL] ‘his/their bird’
Fried (2010): Kots’a=n@ Kos’i=la [school=ACC teacher=PL] ‘school’s teacher’
koZe=n@ satC_ha [self=ACC place] ‘one’s own place’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
nokə mohton undər wa
[that tree tall be]
’That tree is tall.’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
alma mohtun
[fruit tree]
‘fruit tree’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
au-g@ wil@-k@-tCo
[man=SG.INDEF work-VBZ-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A man is working.’
aku-g@ Cat’@=n@ jiX-tCo
[woman=SG.INDEF child=ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A woman hit the child.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment:
LOC =da
INST =Rala
ABL =sa
PRED.POSS  gaN
Example:
atCaN Roni=n@ k_heCaN=Rala jiX-tC@ ala-tC@
[3SG sheep=ACC gun=INST hit-IPFV kill-PFV]
‘He shot and killed the antelope.’
nok@ au silaN=sa @r-tC@
[that man Xining=ABL come-PVF]
‘That man came from Xining.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: Fried discusses only aspect marking, imperfective aspect is used to refer to present tense reference

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Detailed comment:
Todaeva: Suffixes -ov(-vo), -dZE
Fried: perfective aspect
Example:
kEl-o [talk-PST]
la:-dZE [weep-PST]

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Detailed comment:
Todaeva: Suffixes -m, -nE
Fried: -gi/-gəwa
Example:
rE-m [come-FUT]
tani-nE [find.out-FUT]

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
CoNjisa atCaN @l@ o-t@-m
[originally 3SG NEG go-IMP-NARR]
he doesn’t usually go.’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
CoNjisa atCaN @l@ o-t@-m
[originally 3SG NEG go-IMP-NARR]
he doesn’t usually go.’

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Comment: Recipients are marked by the locative case, monotransitive patients by the accusative case.
Example:
aku-g@ Cat’@=n@ jiX-tCo
[woman=SG.INDEF child=ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A woman hit the child.’
au=g@ aku=g@=da samt@X=g@ oX-tCo
[boy=SG.INDEF girl=SG.INDEF=LOC gift=SG.INDEF give-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A boy gave a gift to a girl.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Example: ndZE- [look] - ndZEGE- [look-CAUS] ‘let sb look’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example: EkE- [hit] ‘hit’ - EkE-tSi- [hit-RECIP] ‘hit each other’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment: “Of the two modal auxiliary verbs, khər ‘be required’ immediately follows uninflected lexical verbs, and indicates deontic necessity when used as an auxiliary verb.”
Example:
ənə=nə amaŋ=da war khər-saŋ ba-u
[this=ACC mouth=LOC hold be.required-PERF.NMLZ COP2.OBJ-Q]
‘Should (I) hold this up to (my) mouth?’

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Comment: Forms are called ‘compound’, but the meaning and function of the components is not clear.
Detailed comment: bE, ta - personal pronouns, ndZaN - meaning unclear

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Comment: it is the same as the attributive copula
Example:
dortɕə=da bəndzə=gə wa
[Dorje=LOC notebook= SG.INDEF COP1.OBJ]
‘Dorje has a notebook.’
nokə mohton undər wa
[that tree tall COP1.OBJ]
‘That tree is tall.’

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example:
CoNjisa atCaN @l@ o-t@-m
[originally 3SG NEG go-IMP-NARR]
‘he doesn’t usually go.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’
t_h@r=n@ XitChu=da Kots’a datCorn=n@ tCark@-tC@-tCo
[that=ACC next.day=LOC school report=ACC post-PFV-IPFV.OBJ]
‘On the next day the school posted a report.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’
t_h@r=n@ XitChu=da Kots’a datCorn=n@ tCark@-tC@-tCo
[that=ACC next.day=LOC school report=ACC post-PFV-IPFV.OBJ]
‘On the next day the school posted a report.’

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’
t_h@r=n@ XitChu=da Kots’a datCorn=n@ tCark@-tC@-tCo
[that=ACC next.day=LOC school report=ACC post-PFV-IPFV.OBJ]
‘On the next day the school posted a report.’

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Detailed comment:
verbal imperative: tEgE
verbal declarative: lE, sE

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Detailed comment:
nominal: gi/ginE
verbal imperative: tEgE
verbal declarative: lE, sE
nominal and for PTCP of the future tense: Si/So

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Example: ndZE- [look] - ndZEGE- [look-CAUS] ‘let sb look’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Example:
atɕaŋ khəl~khəl-tɕə
[3SG speak~CONT-PFV]
‘He talked and talked (for a long time).’

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?
Comment: reduplicated nouns do not constitute a phonological unit

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Example:
pətə~pətə=la=tshaŋ
[1DU/PAU/PL.EXCL~1DU/PAU/PL.EXCL =PL=family]
’Our families will go together.’
atɕaŋ jaksa~jaksa wa
[3SG pretty~INT COP1.OBJ]
’She is very beautiful.’
teraŋ~teraŋ (χamdə) ərə
[four~four together come]
‘Come four by four.’

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Detailed comment: Suffix =Rula

Feature: Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Comment: Not mentioned, whether plural forms can be used adnominally.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Detailed comment: 1SG bE, 2SG tSE, 3SG NgaN, 1PL bEdE/mangE, 2PL ta, 3PL NgaNlE

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Detailed comment: 1SG bE, 2SG tSE, 3SG NgaN, 1PL bEdE/mangE, 2PL ta, 3PL NgaNlE

Feature: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Example: χani ‘all’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Detailed comment: dat=loc
Example:
tCaCi=da wer@ wa
[Jiashi=DAT/LOC wife COP.OBJ]
‘Jiashi has a wife.’
tCaCi=da kormu wa-u
[Jiashi=DAT/LOC money COP.OBJ-Q]
‘Does Jiashi have any money?’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Detailed comment: dat=loc
Example:
tCaCi=da wer@ wa
[Jiashi=DAT/LOC wife COP.OBJ]
‘Jiashi has a wife.’
tCaCi=da kormu wa-u
[Jiashi=DAT/LOC money COP.OBJ-Q]
‘Does Jiashi have any money?’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Detailed comment:
-nu/-u/-mu
“The most common strategy for forming a true polar question (i.e. a polar question to which neither an affirmative nor a negative answer is expected more than the alternative) is by means of the question suffix -u. When -u is suffixed to imperfective lexical verbs, it
replaces the imperfective suffix (-tɕi/-tɕo). Similarly, when it is suffixed to perfective verbs, it replaces the perfective suffixes -to and -tɕə.”

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Detailed comment:
suffixes 1SG -jE, 3SG/PL -gE
2SG bare verb stem
all persons: -sE

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Example: Not mentioned.

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Comment: there is a subjective/objective differentiation: tense/aspect markers differ according to person: one marker for 1st person, 1 marker for 2nd and 3rd person

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Comment: Only content interrogative pronouns are mentioned: kaN ‘who’ and jaN ‘what’

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Detailed comment: "Interrogative phrases occur in situ in Bao’an content questions.”

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Example:
rəmo ənə phətɕə-saŋ khoŋ silaŋ=da χatcə-to
[painting this paint-PFV.NMLZ person Xining=LOC leave-PFV] ‘The person who painted this painting went to Xining.’

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Example:
atCaN m@nda jiX-tCo
[3SG 1SG.ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘He hit me.’
t_h@r=n@ XitChu=da Kots’a datCorn=n@ tCark@-tC@-tCo
[that=ACC next.day=LOC school report=ACC post-PFV-IPFV.OBJ]
‘On the next day the school posted a report.’
au-g@ wil@-k@-tCo
[man=SG.INDEF work-VBZ-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A man is working.’
aku-g@ Cat’@=n@ jiX-tCo
[woman=SG.INDEF child=ACC hit-IPFV.OBJ]
‘A woman hit the child.’

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Comment: “The accusative enclitic =nə is typically optional when the subject of the clause is expressed lexically.”

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Detailed comment: 1SG bE, 2SG tSE, 3SG NgaN, 1PL bEdE/mangE, 2PL ta, 3PL NgaNlE

Feature: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Comment: Controversial sources: Fried (2010): possessor is marked, possessed unmarked; Todaeva (1997): possessor is marked on the possessed in phrases with pronominal possessor, no information on phrases with nominal possessor
Example:
Todaeva (1997): bEndZEr [bird] - bEndZer-nE [bird-3SG/PL] ‘his/their bird’
Fried (2010): Kots’a=n@ Kos’i=la [school=ACC teacher=PL] ‘school’s teacher’
koZe=n@ satC_ha [self=ACC place] ‘one’s own place’

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Comment: Controversial sources: Fried (2010): possessor is marked, possessed unmarked; Todaeva (1997): possessor is marked on the possessed in phrases with pronominal possessor, no information on phrases with nominal possessor
Example:
Todaeva (1997): bEndZEr [bird] - bEndZer-nE [bird-3SG/PL] ‘his/their bird’
Fried (2010): Kots’a=n@ Kos’i=la [school=ACC teacher=PL] ‘school’s teacher’
koZe=n@ satC_ha [self=ACC place] ‘one’s own place’

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Example:
pə koʑə=da thəmthoχ htɕəl wa
1SG self=LOC mianpian prepare COP1.OBJ ‘I made myself mianpian noodles.’

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Is there an initial velar nasal?
Example: NgE ‘saddle’, Nasi ‘early’

Feature: Is there an initial r-?
Example: rE- ‘to come’, roN ‘prefecture’, raN ‘informal’, ra ‘courtyard’, r@mo ‘picture’

Feature: Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Detailed comment: typical syllable structures: V, VC, CV, CVC, CCV, CCVC

Feature: Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Example:
pi ‘to stand’ - bi ‘COP.SUBJ’
ka ‘pillar’ - ga ‘saddle’

Feature: Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Detailed comment: It is stated explicitly (“intensity of the property quality is expressed by the word ‘samyj’ preposed to the adjective or the reduplication of the quality adjective”), but there are no examples available.

Feature: Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Detailed comment: There is a bE-tSE opposition in NOM.SG, bEdE/mangE-ta opposition in NOM.PL and MenE-tSEnE opposition in GEN.SG

Feature: Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Detailed comment:
1SG NOM bE, 
GEN mEnE, 
ACC/DAT na:dE, 
ABL na:sE, bEsE, 
INST/COM bEGalE

Feature: Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?
Detailed comment: There are adverbial participles, but there are no clausal examples available.

Feature: Are specific non-finite and finite suffixes expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Can 1PL marker be augmented by a collective plural marker?
Example:
pətə-la [1PL.EXCL-PL]
maŋgə-la [1PL.INCL-PL]

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Are there deranked purpose clauses?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be left implicit when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Is there a voicing distinction in fricatives?
Comment: Not clear: the consonants are aspirated and/or voiceless.

Feature: Are there two separate liquid phonemes (r/l)?
Is there vowel length distinction?
Detailed comment:
no more
Hugjiltu: depends on the dialect: in Qinghai Bonan there is vowel length distinction
Rybatzki: Bonan not mentioned among languages that lost vowel length distinction

Feature: Are causative posture verbs derived and static-dynamic verbs basic?
Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?
Can scalar additive operators (‘even’) also be used in non-scalar contexts (also)?
Is there a reflexive-possessive affix?
Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example:
tɕerənbotɕhi=da tɕama ʁar [Zongkaba=LOC cook two]
‘Zongkaba had two cooks.’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Example:
aku=gə ɕaʑə=nə
[woman=SG.INDEF child=ACC]
‘A woman hit the child.’
aku=gə ɕaʑə jiχ-tɕo
[girl= SG.INDEF child hit-IMPF.OBJ]
’A woman hit a child/children.’

Feature: Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Detailed comment:
polar: mu
content: no marking

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?
Can demonstrative/interrogative verbs be derived from pronouns and light verbs ‘to do’?
Are causative and passive expressed by a formally identical marker?
Detailed comment: no passive

Feature: Are converb suffixes and deverbal noun suffixes formally identical?
Are quotative markers adverbial derivations from a verb ‘to say’?
Can relational adpositions (e.g. ‘under’) be derived from a place noun (e.g. ‘bottom’) and a locational suffix (e.g. at LOC)?
Are hortatives/purposives encoded by the same marker (eventually involving a converb of the verb ‘to say’)?
Are denominal verbalizers and deverbal suffixes sharing comparable actional semantics expressed by the same marker?
Is ‘it is becoming if’ grammaticalized in deontic modality?
Is imperative form for 2SG identical to bare verb root?
Is person marking on the verb formally identical to independent personal pronouns?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a meaning ‘to see’?
Can a copula be derived from original posture verbs?
Can the notional subject of a want complement clause be expressed overtly when it is coreferential with the wanter?
Are ‘foot’ and ‘leg’ expressed by the same term?
Are there balanced purpose clauses?
Is there an adposition or a particle formally similar to the verb?
Is completive aspect expressed by a marker formally identical to the verb ’to put/throw away’?
Are there adpositions to mark core NPs?
Are there adpositions to mark oblique NPs?
Are there three laryngeal contrasts for stops?
Can numeral precede the noun?
Example:
mannə çəŋga=da da sowo ʁar udər wo
[1PL.INCL.COLL.GEN Cenga=LOC also important two day be]
‘Here in Cenga, there are also two important days.’

Feature: Can numeral follow the noun?
Example:
tɕerənbotɕhi=da tɕama ʁar [Zongkaba=LOC cook two]
‘Zongkaba had two cooks.’

Feature: Can demonstrative precede the noun?
Example:
ənə deku amtə wa
[this food delicious be]
‘This food is delicious.’

Feature: Can demonstrative follow the noun?
Can adnominal possessor precede the possessed noun?
Detailed comment:
Controversial sources: Fried (2010): possessor is marked, possessed unmarked; Todaeva (1997): possessor is marked on the possessed in phrases with pronominal possessor, no information on phrases with nominal possessor
According to Fried (2010), the order would be 1, according to Todaeva (1997) 0

Feature: Can adnominal possessor follow the possessed noun?
Detailed comment:
Controversial sources: Fried (2010): possessor is marked, possessed unmarked; Todaeva (1997): possessor is marked on the possessed in phrases with pronominal possessor, no information on phrases with nominal possessor
According to Fried (2010), the order would be 0, according to Todaeva (1997) 1/

Feature: Can adnominal property word precede the noun?
Can adnominal property word follow the noun?
Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) precede the noun?
Example:
khəthə=ku adzi iχtɕədu aku χani=nə khəl-tɕi-saŋ
[home.LOC=IMPF.NMLZ older.sister younger.sister girl all=ACC say-IMPF.SUBJ-POS]
‘(This) includes (lit. ‘says (to)’) all older sisters, younger sisters, and girls who are at home.’

Feature: Can adnominal collective universal quantifier (‘all’) follow the noun?
Is there height vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Is there an initial l-?
Do numerals have the same form in attributive and predicative use?
Are instrumental and comitative expressed by the same marker?
Is the meaning ‘to hunt’ expressed as noun+denominalizer?
Are the meanings ‘to see’ and ‘to try’ expressed by formally identical verbs?
What is the order of personal possessive suffixes and case suffixes?
Possible Values: 0: one category missing; 1: POSS-case; 2: case-POSS; 3: both

Is the pragmatically unmarked order of VS in intransitive clauses?
